title: Accept dependencies file for external and require options
body:
For projects I create both a `vendor.js` and `app.js` files that contain third-party libraries and application's code respectively. I prefer using npm scripts for build process. I have the next scripts in my `package.json` that do this job:

```
...
"scripts": {
  "build:app": "browserify  index.js -x dependency1 -x dependency2 ... -x dependencyN -t [ babelify --presets [es2015 react] ] | uglifyjs -mc -o dist/app.min.js",
  "build:vendor": "browserify -r dependency1 -r dependency2 ... -x dependencyN -o dist/vendor.js"
},
...
```

It works, but as dependencies increase or decrease, it's kind of annoying to maintain `build:app` and `build:vendor` scripts.
A non-cli solution I'm working on (but I'm not sure of it) is to create `build_vendor.js` and `build_app.js` so I use browserify's API. It works but when I need to use something like uglify I have to use it's API too losing all command line I would've liked to have.
I was wondering if there is a way to pass, let's say a `dependencies.json` file to --external and --require options so `dependencies.json` looks something like:

```
[
   "dependency1",
   "dependency2",
   ...
   "dependencyN"
]
```

And scripts will be something like:

```
...
"scripts": {
  "build:app": "browserify index.js --external dependencies.json -o dist/app.js",
  "build:vendor": "browserify --require dependencies.json -o dist/vendor.js"
},
...
```

Would it be worth for a PR? If it would, where should I start or what browserify dependency should I fork to code this PR?

Thanks in advance

title: Transform buffer chunk weirdness
use memoized path.relative
body: Per #1543 @terinjokes

title: Caching the results of path.relative reduces rebuild times
body:
I did a bit of profiling with [devtool](https://github.com/Jam3/devtool) and noticed that a bunch of time is spent in `path.relative` during rebuilds, for the most part repeating path resolutions that have already been done.

Memoizing it's results decreases my rebuild times by about 10%. I made a little module for shimming path.relative to make this happen, [cached-path-relative](https://github.com/ashaffer/cached-path-relative). But maybe it'd be best to have browserify and its dependencies use this or something like it explicitly?

title: failure to resolve transform when run from subdirectory within project
body:
When running browserify + transforms from a subdirectory within a project, it will fail with the following error:

```
C:path\subdir> npm run browserify -t hyperxify main.js > bundle.js  # [1]

Error: Cannot find module 'C:\path\hyperxify' from 'C:\path'
    at C:\path\node_modules\resolve\lib\async.js:55:21
    at load (C:\path\node_modules\resolve\lib\async.js:
69:43)
    at onex (C:\path\node_modules\resolve\lib\async.js:
92:31)
    at C:\path\node_modules\resolve\lib\async.js:22:47
    at FSReqWrap.oncomplete (fs.js:82:15)

# [1] NB: browserify binary is aliased as a script, due to local installation of browserify
```

I've verified that the transform is resolved if I run browserify from the root of the project.  I've also verified that the `resolve()` module will properly find the transform (in this case, hyperxify) if called directly from a script in the subdirectory.

title: Can Browserify be used on server-side Node.js?
body:
Can Browserify be used on server-side Node.js?

The Node.js modules system is great, but it leads to some bloat on the filesystem.  In most cases, this filesystem bloat isn't really an issue.  However, our team has been exploring AWS Lambda, and I'm sure there are similar server-style environments where a smaller code footprint would be helpful.  Which is why I thought of Browserify, since it pulls only the dependencies it needs.

Is it possible and if it is, does anyone know if there is any extra configuration needed to make it work properly in a server-style environment?

title: Package replacement as a browser field
body:
Hello @substack @feross @zertosh @hughsk!

There is a chance Iâ€™m missing something, but is there any specific reason why we cannot implement package replacement in `browser` field, not only the file replacement?

``` json
"browser": "package-analog-for-browser",
"browser": {
  "some-node-package": "some-browser-package"
}
```

instead of 

``` json
"browser": "./package-shim.js",
"browser": {
  "some-node-package": "./some-node-package-shim.js"
}
```

Often I see a situation where packages are just being targeted to single platform and have 1:1 analog in other platform, e. g: 
- [webaudio](https://www.npmjs.com/package/webaudio) / [baudio](https://www.npmjs.com/package/baudio)
- [gl-shader-output](https://www.npmjs.com/package/gl-shader-output) / [nogl-shader-output](https://www.npmjs.com/package/nogl-shader-output)
- [audio-speaker](https://www.npmjs.com/package/audio-speaker) / [node-speaker](https://www.npmjs.com/package/node-speaker)
- [glslify](https://www.npmjs.com/package/glslify) / [glslify-sync](https://www.npmjs.com/package/glslify-sync) for node.
- any of the [browser-builtins](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/lib/builtins.js) etc.

In some cases, like the [glslify-sync](https://github.com/vorg/glslify-sync), absence of that feature is really painful, for if we had the opportunity to set package replacement, we could avoid [duplicating code](https://github.com/vorg/glslify-sync/blob/master/transform.js) and keep consistent API.

There are modules like aliasify, but they are... too opinionated and do not actually solve the cases like above.

title: unable to emit full absolute file paths for dependencies
body:
I am unable to make browserify output full absolute file paths for modules. Is this possible?

For example, I expected browserify to produce full file paths as dependency keys when executing:

```
browserify -x /Users/me/code/a.js bundle.js
```

given the following files:

```
$ cat a.js 
module.exports = function () {return 'aaaa';}
$ cat bundle.js
var a = require('./a.js');
console.log(a());
```

But instead the output dependencies of `bundle.js` from browserify look like this:

```
{"./a.js":"/a.js"}]},{},[1]
```

Is it possible to make browserify output the full file path like this?:

```
{"./a.js":"/Users/me/code/a.js"}]},{},[1]
```

Looking through https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/8f7adc96e3ed59c299d078405a463860f5409ba6/index.js#L695-L702,
this code seems strange:

```
            if (self._external.indexOf(rfile) >= 0) {
                row.deps[key] = rfile;
            }
            if (self._external.indexOf(afile) >= 0) {
                row.deps[key] = rfile;
            }
```

whether we find the relative file (`rfile`) or absolute file (`afile`) in `_external`, we always set `row.deps[key]` to `rfile`. Why don't we set `row.deps[key]` to `afile` ever?

Perhaps it's something to do with how we append both the relative file path and the file path itself to `_externals`:
https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/8f7adc96e3ed59c299d078405a463860f5409ba6/index.js#L255-L257

```
    this._external.push(file);
    this._external.push('/' + path.relative(basedir, file));
```

But I don't really understand why this is done.

title: Having an issue with 'browser' field
body:
Here's my setup:
- node v5.0.0
- npm v3.3.6
- browserify v13.0.0

Here's my package.json

``` json
{
  "name": "emcee-craft",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "main": "./lib/emcee-craft.js",
  "scripts": {
    "build": "browserify browser.js -o ./dist/app.js"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "minecraft-data": "1.2.6",
    "underscore": "1.8.3"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "browserify": "13.0.0"
  }
}
```

my project structure is as follows:

```
- package.json
- browser.js
- lib/
    - emcee-craft.js
- dist/
    - index.html
    - app.js (browserify output)
```

I want `lib/emcee-craft.js` loaded when using node, and `browser.js` loaded when browserify-ing (which requires `lib/emcee-craft.js`).

When I specify `"browser": "browser.js"` in my package.json and build with browserify, `browser.js` is included in my browserify package, but `lib/emcee-craft.js` is not.
However, when I specify `"browser": { "browser.js": "browser.js" }` everything is included in the package, and I can run it in the browser without a problem.

I'm not really sure why the latter works and not the former; to me they seem like the same thing. I've read the [browser field section](https://github.com/substack/browserify-handbook#browser-field) of the browserify handbook, but didn't find any answers there. Is there anything that I'm missing?

title: Rhino
Bug introduced in 12.0.1 (Breakage with symlink + Babelify)
body:
### Overview

The [single line](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/commit/ec829dfac8380873ed8aee9c995220638082af55#diff-168726dbe96b3ce427e7fedce31bb0bcR487) (excluding tests) changed in patch release 12.0.1 causes breakage in applications using symlinks and Babelify.

(I discovered this today, as the latest release of [grunt-browserify](https://github.com/jmreidy/grunt-browserify) upgrades Browserify from v11 to v13.)
### Specifics

I have a project which uses symlinks in accordance with the [Browserify Handbook](https://github.com/substack/browserify-handbook#symlink), arranged as follows:

```
node_modules/
â”œâ”€â”€ ...
â””â”€â”€ appName   -- symlink to 'src/' directory

src/
â”œâ”€â”€ ...
â””â”€â”€ main.js

...

.babelrc      -- where Babelify looks for its parameters
...
```

I then simply execute (the Grunt equivalent of):

``` bash
browserify src/main.js -o build/app-name.js -s AppName -t babelify
```

This works perfectly through Browserify 12.0.0, but as of 12.0.1 and beyond, I see the error:

```
ParseError: 'import' and 'export' may appear only with 'sourceType: module'
```

This error does not occur (and the build succeeds) if I don't use the symlink in my `import`s.

As implied above, everything works as it used to if I simply revert [the offending line](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/index.js#L489) in index.js:
`cb(err, res, pkg, file);` â†’ `cb(err, res, pkg);`

title: Pipe a readable stream into browserify
Cannot find module './charset.js'
Transform in package.json on symlinked modules not working in npm3
body:
**Environment:** node@5.70 npm@3.75 browserify@13.0.0 babelify@7.2.0

Trying to build an app that worked with `npm@2` and `babelify@6` but having problems upgrading to `npm@3` and `babelify@7`. Allow me to try and explain the problem.
- In `app/node_modules` I have modules installed via `npm install` and local modules symlinked via `npm link`. 
- The local modules have browserify transforms specified in their `package.json` e.g -

``` json
...
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "babel-preset-es2015": "^6.5.0",
    "babelify": "^7.2.0"
  },
  "browserify": {
    "transform": [
      [
        "babelify",
        {
          "presets": [
            "es2015"
          ]
        }
      ]
    ]
  }
...
```

Attempting to build I get error:

`"Browserify Error: Couldn't find preset "es2015" relative to directory"`

npm 3 has flattened out the dependency tree, so the `babel-preset-es2015` the symlinked module needs are in the `node_modules` of `app`. According to the explanation by @substack [here](https://github.com/substack/browserify-handbook#how-node_modules-works) and this example [here](https://github.com/maxogden/art-of-node/#how-require-works) browserify should walk up the tree from the symlinked module to `app` and check in the `node_modules` there, but it doesn't seem to be doing this. 

My directory layout looks like this:

```
~/projects
  |-- app
    |-- entry.js (this file can see babel-preset just fine)
    |-- node_modules
       |-- babel-preset-es2015
       |-- my-module (symlink pointing at ~/projects/modules-shared/my-module)
          |-- index.js (we want babelify to transform this file)
  |-- modules-shared
     |-- my-module
```

If I install `babel-preset-es2015` in the `modules-shared` folder, browserify finds the preset. 

I get the impression from looking through other issues that this sort of problem has come up before and has long been fixed, so I wonder why I have the problem now.

title: Cannot find module on windows when using -r / -x
body:
We are building an application that embeds plugins and we are using windows. 

Plugins are separate js files built with:
`browserify -x react -x ./common/react/Registry.js -d plugin1/Plugin1.js -o plugin1/bundle.js`
where react and ./common/react/Registry.js are shared libraries, thus excluded from the plugins' bundle using the -x switch.

Main application is built with:
`browserify -r react -r ./common/react/Registry.js -d app/app.js -o app/bundle.js`
where react and ./common/react/Registry.js are made available for plugins using the -r switch

We are getting the following error when loading plugins:
`Uncaught Error: Cannot find module '/common\react\Registry.js'`

And have tracked it down to this line being generated in plugin's bundle.js:
`...},{"../../../common/react/Registry":"/common\\react\\Registry.js","react":"react"}]},{},[1])`
and when manually changed to: 
`...},{"../../../common/react/Registry":"/common/react/Registry.js","react":"react"}]},{},[1])`
works fine. Seems that some parts of browserify use the unix style path separators but others use the OS path separators.

We have changed some lines in browserify index.js such that all paths use unix style path separators. We have added .replace(/\/g, '/') in all cases where path is used and it seems to have fixed the problem.

Should you require a test case, we would be happy to decompose the application down to a simple test case.

Attached is a diff of the index.js file.

[index.js.diff.txt](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/files/153094/index.js.diff.txt)

title: Can't use builtins with browserField false
body:
Hi,

I can't use `opts.builtins` with `opts.browserField = false` because it's using a different resolver.

Does anyone have an alternative suggestion?

title: ignoreMissing does not work for modules with more than one missing module
body:
Using the `ignoreMissing` or `im` option, it appears that things are ok if only one module is missing, as the tests in https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/b7cf5bef990a6823d14e2d437e15112aa6b3adfa/test/ignore_missing.js#L4 are only testing ony missing module and not two.

I suspect that there should be another test added that missing 2 modules works fine as well.

title: Is it possible to pass plugin options through Browserify (files, opts)
body:
I am using Browserify through its Meteor wrapper `cosmos:browserify`. I wanted to use `browserify-resolutions` to remove duplicated packages. `browserify-resolutions` requires an option passed through `plugin` function ([see here](https://github.com/Updater/browserify-resolutions#how-to-use)).

However, with `cosmos:browserify` I can only put options in a `json` file and `cosmos:browserify` passes it to `Browserify (files, opts)`; it looks like no calls to `plugin` is made. Is there a way I can pass options to a specific plugin through `opts`?

title: Avoid relative paths by supporting local_modules
body:
Use the same algorithm of discovery which is used for `node_modules` and described [here](https://github.com/substack/browserify-handbook#organizing-modules), but for folders called `local_modules`. This would allow relative paths to stop being used:
- without having to create symlinks, postinstall or git hooks, 
- no path variable configuration
- no extra local .gitignore with include rules for each module
- it would prevent destruction of code via accidental deletion of the node_modules directory
- allow node_modules to be excluded in [Sublime Text](https://github.com/SublimeTextIssues/Core/issues/1115) without excluding local modules
- create a clear distinction between published modules and local modules

title: Broswerify bundles but doesn't work
Incompatible bundles generated with .external()
[question] Is there a way to force browserify to not use "browser" in package.json ?
Use `inherits` package for `util.inherits` code
body:
When browserify sees `Buffer.isBuffer` in user code, it uses [is-buffer](https://www.npmjs.com/package/is-buffer) (363 bytes) instead of including the whole `buffer` package (6446 bytes).

Let's do the same when browserify sees `util.inherits`. Let's use `inherits` (434 bytes) instead of including the whole `util` package (3315 bytes).

(All sizes were calculated with `browserify -r <package> | uglifyjs -m | gzip | wc -c`)

title: --node doesn't work
body:
I am using **browserify v13.0.0**

I have an `a.js` which just has a `module.exports = {a: 1}`

And I run browserify as so:
`browserify --node --debug a.js > bundle.js`

In the **node REPL**, 

```
> require ('./bundle.js')
{}
>
```

Why the `{}` ? Shouldn't it give me `{a: 1}`?

Although I've reduced my problem to the simplest case, this behavior is stopping me from bundling a project involving multiple coffeescript files into a single file for node & browsers.

Ive also tried `--bare`, `--no-builtins`, `--no-bf`

title: browserifying with the debug flag and concating with other scripts does not work
body:
the `debug` flag causes a semicolon to not get appended as the last character in the bundle.

if run as part of a build and concatenated with other files, this throws a runtime error.

also see https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/540 and https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/496

``` coffee
browserify
  detectGlobals: no
  entries: [ ... ]
  debug: true # offending line
  cache: {}
  packageCache: {}
.transform('browserify-shim', { global: true })
.bundle()
.pipe source 'bundle.js'
.pipe gulp.dest DISTDIR
```

title: Removing a line of code that tried to convince me that I was crazy
Syntax error always shows the same line: `throw er; // Unhandled 'error' event`
body:
Any syntax error seems to show the same error line which is not the source code that has contains error when using gulp + browserify.

I've seen many error reports that have the exact same thing and people are always perplexed as to what is actually wrong.

some variant of:

```
events.js:72
        throw er; // Unhandled 'error' event
              ^
SyntaxError: Unexpected token
```

I've traced it to `Browserify.prototype._syntax` so far.

title: Getting Uncaught TypeError: fs.readdirSync is not a function when using Browserify with Nutritionix NodeJS client library
body:
I've been trying to use Browserify with Nutritionix NodeJS client library and I keep running into an error. I made a Stack Overflow issue which explains in detail what my problem is and a solution which someone offered but didn't work. 

Here is the link: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/34735903/getting-uncaught-typeerror-fs-readdirsync-is-not-a-function-when-using-browseri

I know I can require the Nutritionix NodeJS client library in the backend but I would prefer to require it in the front end. Any help is greatly appreciated.

title: Specify flags per-module in package.json to support optional dependencies
body:
I have a package with optional dependencies and wraps require statements in try-catch blocks.

While this works in node, it doesn't work in browserify because it throws bundle errors for modules not being found.

There are some discussions online about this and a transform meant for this:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/26127804/browserify-building-with-dependencies-that-have-require-statements-in-try-catch
https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/653
https://github.com/devongovett/browserify-optional

It seems like the ideal solution is to specify something like `--ignore-missing` in the package.json file of my package so that it won't fail. Specifying this at the top root package when running browserify clearly doesn't make sense.

Is there any way to do this, or a better approach I should take?

title: b.bundle: Return readableStream and pass callback?

`index.js`, `LICENSE`, `changelog.markdown`, `package.json` & `readme.markdown` are automatically included, see https://docs.npmjs.com/files/package.json#files and https://github.com/feross/buffer/pull/98.

cannot find module 'is-buffer' in version 13.x.x (works in 12.0.2)
body:
Hello, upgrading to browserify 13.x.x, I came across an error when I tried to use it:   

```
Error: Cannot find module 'is-buffer'

```

I am using node v5.4.1 and npm 3.3.12

Reverting to 12.x.x make the problem go away. I looked into it on these issues and I see two issues that may very well be related: #1482  and #1476 , the one @feross was working on. looks like it was for a good reason: a sizable increase in speed.

If I have mistakenly associated my error with these issues, feel free to close this. I am mostly submitting the issue to see if anyone else has the problem, or there is something I need to know about buffers in the most current versions of node/browserify I am not aware of.

thanks very much for your time

title: Don't mess with Buffer.prototype (v13)
body:
https://github.com/feross/typedarray-to-buffer/issues/3 explains all.

With your latest version somehow this code gets modified from

```
function (arr) {
      arr.__proto__ = Buffer.prototype
      return arr
}
```

to

```
Buffer._augment
```

How come? It is breaking in my videomail app ...

title: allow wildcard on `b.external` to require any subpath from external vendor bundle
Fill in some documentation gaps
body:
This fills in several holes in the documentation, including the one pointed out in #1478.

The major exception is `exposeAll` (see also #1296). It seems it does not yet work as intended (#1292 and #1293), so it may be for the better that it is undocumented.

I'll merge this in myself at some point if there are no raised issues.

title: Specifying paths in package.json
Where does 'require' option come from? Why is it not covered in docs?
Enhancement: Output dependency list in makefile format
body:
This would ease inter-operation with the [Ninja build system](https://ninja-build.org) and it's [depfiles](https://ninja-build.org/manual.html#_depfile). Currently I have to write horrible commands like below to get this inter-op (using [ninja-build-gen](https://github.com/jeanlauliac/ninja-build-gen)).

``` coffeescript
#browserify and put dependency list in $out.d in makefile format using
#relative paths
ninja.rule('browserify')
    .run("echo -n '$out: ' > $out.d 
          && browserify $in --list | sed 's!#{__dirname}/!!' | tr '\\n' ' ' >> $out.d 
          && browserify $in -o $out")
    .depfile('$out.d')
```

This could of course also be handled in Ninja but the author seems very hesitant to add anything not aimed at large C/C++ codebase compilation. Feel free to close if you don't think it's a needed feature for Browserify though.

title: buffer@4
body:
Node.js removed the `buffer.toArrayBuffer()` API sometime during node 0.11. Users who rely on it will have code that doesn't work in node.js, which is unfortunate.

`feross/buffer` v4.0.0 removed `buffer.toArrayBuffer()` to have parity with node.js.

Going forward, users can just use `buffer.buffer` to get an `ArrayBuffer` since `Buffer` is just a subclass of `Uint8Array` in both node.js and the browser.

This is a breaking change, since we're removing a method from the buffer.

I'm only sending this PR now, since buffer v4.1.0 has a 30% performance increase for lots of the buffer methods and I want users to have that :+1:

title: (node) warning: possible EventEmitter memory leak detected. 11 reset listeners added. Use emitter.setMaxListeners() to increase limit.

title: SCRIPT5009: 'FormData' is undefined in IE9
body:
On Browserify 12.0.1, request is broken on IE9, some code in request -> form-data: [lib/browser.js](https://github.com/form-data/form-data/blob/master/lib/browser.js) is tripping IE9 (and possibly other versions).

I initially [reported](https://github.com/form-data/form-data/issues/160) this with form-data, but it seems to be more of a Browserify issue.

As a temporary fix, using this [polyfill](https://github.com/francois2metz/html5-formdata) fixes the issue.

title: Travis CI: Switch from `node` to `4` and `5` to test latest NodeJS v4x.x and v5.x.x versions
browserify won't install if node was installed on OS X using homebrew
Support -r [ ... ]
body:
I'd love a way to add multiple `--require` and `--exclude`s without having to repeat `-r` and `-x`.

You can compile an `app` & `vendor` package today. This example below will write `dist/app.js` without some big libraries, and compile a separate `dist/vendor.js` with those libraries.

```
browserify -r react -r redux -r jquery -o dist/vendor.js
browserify -x react -x redux -x jquery app.js -o dist/app.js
```

It would be simpler if they can be done as an array, like so:

``` sh
vendor=react redux jquery
browserify -r [ $vendor ] -o dist/vendor.js
browserify -x [ $vendor ] app.js -o dist/app.js
```

title: transform not receiving `options._flags` if run through package.json
body:
continuing from https://github.com/davidguttman/cssify/issues/43,

if i call the transform using the command line like

``` bash
browserify . -t such-transform
```

then the transform sees `options._flags`, as described on the [last line of the browserify transform docs](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify#btransformtr-opts)

> Options sent to the browserify constructor are also provided under `opts._flags`. These browserify options are sometimes required if your transform needs to do something different when browserify is run in debug mode, for example.

yet if i call the transform using

``` json
{
  "browserify": {
    "transform": [
      "such-transform"
    ]
  }
}
```

then `options._flags` is undefined.

title: Issue about source maps paths
body: UPDATE: Seems like it's Babel + Babelify + Coverify issue: https://github.com/substack/coverify/issues/23

title: Compile time modules.
body:
Hello,

I'm having a pretty crazy time trying to figure out how to inject compile time modules into the pipeline for bundling. My issue is i'm using babel(babelify) to build an es6 project. When babelify transforms are run, it will auto inline any helpers and polyfills to support the code. This obviously gets ridiculous when every single file contains the same copy of helpers and polyfills. Luckily for me, i am able to opt for external helpers which is awesome. Instead of generating inline helpers, it inline calls into a helper namespace(babelHelpers). The bad news is i need a list of helpers to generate. After babelify transform runs i am able to query it to figure out the project requirements are in terms of helpers. So now i have my helper source string, and i need a way to inject it into the bundle.

The obvious solution would be to concat it end of the built bundle, but i don't want to deal with namespace collisions and want to control my module surface areas. I also played with the idea of using insert-module-globals to resolve the helper with an inline require. I just cant figure out how to insert my compile time sources into the pipeline after the bundler has kicked off.

Thanks in advance.

title: Add tests to .npmignore
body: Tests take ~ 1 Mo in space, maybe we shouldn't ship them to npm ?

title: Replacing the require calls in place
body:
Is it possible to replace the `require` calls in place like in the following example?

Having two files:
- `a.js`
  
  ``` js
   var b = require("./b");
  ```
- `b.js`
  
  ``` js
   module.exports = 42;
  ```

By bundling `a.js` and `b.js` together I want to get a file containing just this:

``` js
var b = 42;
```

I know Browserify creates a nice environment for handling `require` and `module` things, but sometimes that's too much for me. Sometimes I just want to create bundles like in this example, by really replacing the `require` calls.

Does `browserify` have this power or is there a related tool to do that? :thought_balloon:

title: Update module-deps to 4.0.3 (fixes upstream regression)
body:
See https://github.com/substack/module-deps/issues/105

I am hitting this regression in a library that browserify is a dependency of. I would like to ensure that the users of that library do not have an old version of module-deps installed. The only good way to do that is to add a version range in browserify's package configuration (`"module-deps": ">= 4.0.3 < 5"`); so that I can do the same in that library (e.g. `"browserify": ">= 12.0.3 < 13"`).

title: [ browserify / module-deps ] Large UTF8 encoded file can't be compiled correctly
body:
When I try to compile a project which includes a large Angular template file, strange character `ï¿½` appeared in the final output. For example, I may get code like: ```

36æ°ªå¹³å°å…¬å¸ä»…ä¸ºæ‚¨æä¾›åœ¨çº¿äº¤æµã€äº’è”ç½‘ç§å‹Ÿè‚¡æƒæŠ•èµ„ç­‰ç½‘ç»œå¹³å°æœï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¼Œ36æ°ª

``` Then I tracked the code and found the reason for this issue in `module-deps`: `index.js` line:161: ``` javascript var rs = fs.createReadStream(file); ``` When I add option to createReadStream, the problem is resolved. The code is like: ``` javascript var rs = fs.createReadStream(file,{ encoding:'utf8' }); ```

title: file is an object and set opts
Instruction to install globally (`npm install -g`)
body: Probably shouldn't be encouraging people to install globally at this point.

title: Builtins create hidden dependency on Browserify version
body:
I spent most of today teasing out why my webapp bundle was buggy only on my own system and not my co-worker's, with the same `package.json` and the same versions of everything in `node_modules`. Long story short: something depends on the builtin `Buffer`, and my (somewhat old, 8.x from January) copy of Browserify had a bugged version. 

The rest of Browserify's dependency determination system is so explicit and obvious, it completely threw me for a loop to learn that a select set of objects (like `Buffer`) can be populated automatically with whatever happens to be in `node_modules` for Browserify's global installation. 

I can see that this is for compatibility with modules written for node.js, but it's a huge gotcha for this invisible, undeclared dependency to exist between the Browserify version and dependencies of dependencies that one is likely unaware of.

Should builtins need explicit require statements and dependency entries in `package.json`?

P.S: For additional fun: Watchify brings its own version of Browserify with it (with the usual `npm install watchify -g`). If those copies get out of sync, then Browserify and Watchify can build bundles with different versions of the builtins.
